title: Tom Brady loved watching alma mater Michigan beat USC as new rivalries form in Big Ten: 'Kicked their a--'

title: Presidents Cup: The most iconic photos, quotes from Day 2
summary:
The Presidents Cup score sits 5-5 after the Internationals swept the Americans Friday. Let’s look at the best photos and quotes.

Welcome to Playing Through’s daily ritual — Golf Talk Today.

Each day, the crew will discuss various elements of the PGA Tour, LPGA, LIV Golf, and more.

Day 2 brought the energy! Before Day 3 begins at the Presidents Cup, let's rehash the wild ride from Friday.

The International Team swept the Americans, tying the score 5-5. Whatever pep talk happened on their bus after Thursday’s session worked for the Black and Gold team.

They came out with a vengeance and backed into a corner. The Internationals responded in a way that should keep the Americans on their toes.

This group played like one, and the camaraderie was very noticeable. They came together and proved that the Presidents Cup is a must-watch event.

It is something to behold when the Presidents Cup is close like this. Anyone who pushes this event to the side should check themselves because Friday gave the fans quite the show. The International Team will not lie down this weekend and could very well upset the Americans.

After such a fun day, let’s look at some of our favorite photos and quotes from Day 2 at Royal Montreal.

Best photos from Day 2 at the Presidents Cup

The International Team had some fantastic celebrations on Friday. One of my favorite things I saw was the pure bliss on their faces. However, seeing the somber looks on the Americans was also very telling of what happened during the Friday Foursomes session.

Friday’s best quotes from the Presidents Cup

“I saw all four front groups winning points, so I knew I needed to get points and bring it to the game on. Yeah, we’re game on.”

— Si Woo Kim on sinking the 15-footer to secure the sweep

“On a day like today, you tip your cap to the guys that played better; in our case, they played better than we did. They were able to use the crowd behind them to their advantage. But we felt the energy right out of the gate. I hit the first tee shot yesterday in our group, and I hit the first tee shot today. It was the night-and-day difference, I think, just the noise and the energy.”

— Tony Finau on playing against the all-Canadian duo Mackenzie Hughes and Corey Conners

“I like my 11 guys in a dogfight over the next three rounds.”

— Tony Finau on Team USA’s mentality

“To come back and show everyone what this team is made of after a tough day out there yesterday is just incredible. We’ve got a big day tomorrow and a bigger day Sunday. We can enjoy this this evening and then come out incredibly focused. This team knows what it’s capable of now.”

— Adam Scott on the International Team’s performance on Friday

“I think the reason we were able to play so good today, other than these guys going out and performing, was our fans backed us up. I think that gives you momentum, that gives you energy. Just they played a huge factor in our win today.”

— Tom Kim on the atmosphere/fans

ICYMI: Top Stories Around Golf

Canadian best friends Corey Conners, Mackenzie Hughes boss around Team USA at Presidents Cup

Tiger Woods accused of ‘unlawfully hijacking’ Sun Day Red logo; could face legal issues

Presidents Cup: NBC’s John Wood offers valuable insight from caddie perspective

Keegan Bradley reveals Ryder Cup mission for this year’s Presidents Cup at Royal Montreal

Savannah Leigh Richardson is a golf staff writer for SB Nation’s Playing Through. For more golf coverage, follow us @_PlayingThrough on all major social platforms. You can also follow her on Twitter @SportsGirlSL and Instagram @golf_girl_sl.

title: Your daily NFL trivia game, Saturday edition
summary:
Think you can figure out what NFL player we’re talking about? You’ll get five clues to figure him out.

We’re back for another day of the SB Nation in-5 daily trivia game, and we’re returning to our system of a new article each day for the game.

We tried using a single article for the game, updated with the latest game each day, but it was creating a bit of an unwieldy experience in the comments. So, we’ll have the current day’s game plus the previous three days in each new article. That way, you can catch up if you miss a day.

Game instructions are at the bottom if you’re new to the game!

What we need from you

  1. Play the game
  2. Share your result in the comments and on social media
  3. Provide feedback (Google Form or in comments below)

See SB Nation in-5 game instructions below the game.

Today’s SB Nation in-5 game

Friday’s SB Nation in-5 game

Thursday’s SB Nation in-5 game

Wednesday’s game

SB Nation in-5 instructions

The goal of the game is to guess the correct random NFL player with the help of up to five clues. We’ll mix in BOTH ACTIVE AND RETIRED PLAYERS this week. It won’t be easy to figure it out in one or two guesses, but some of you might be able to nail it. It will be a mix of well-known players and some “that guys” that we haven’t thought of in some time. The game will appear in slot #3 of the SB Nation layout each morning, with occasional movement later in the day.

After you correctly guess the player, you can click “Share Results” to share how you did down in the comments and on social media. We won’t go into other details about the game as we’d like your feedback on it. How it plays, what you think of it, the difficulty level, and anything else you can think of that will let us know what you think and how we can improve the game. You can provide feedback in the comments of this article, or you can fill out this Google Form.

Enjoy!

title: ‘Pitbull’ Gallagher on course for duel with Bellingham in Madrid derby
summary:
Former Chelsea midfielder looks at home in an Atlético shirt and can underline his worth against Real Madrid on Sunday

There were 18,752 fans there the day the Valley celebrated its hundredth birthday and Jude Bellingham made his first league start, at 16 years and 77 days. Charlton were second in the Championship, unbeaten in six games, and had the chance to go top. But on a bad tempered September afternoon in 2019 during which their coach, Lee Bowyer, was sent off for grabbing a spare ball that had been thrown on to the pitch, they were defeated 1-0 by Birmingham City and ended up relegated.

It was Bellingham who scored the goal, of course, celebrating arms wide before the stands. “As the son of one of the most prolific strikers to have graced the non-league game, he should have learned a thing or two,” said the Observer’s match report.

Continue reading...

title: Football campaign for boardroom diversity opens doors at House of Lords
summary:
Women in Football gives progress update at Westminster on its Open Doors agenda and says it will unveil ‘exciting news’

Before the 2023 Women’s World Cup final the Fifa president, Gianni Infantino, urged women to “push at the doors” of power in their drive for equality. “With men, with Fifa, you will find open doors,” he said. “Just push the doors. I say to all the women – and you know I have four daughters, so I have a few at home – that you have the power to change.

“Pick the right battles. Pick the right fights. You have the power to convince us men what we have to do and what we don’t have to do. You do it. Just do it.”

Continue reading...

title: South Africa’s Ronwen Wiliams: ‘I would say that football saved my life’
summary:
Goalkeeper on playing on despite family bereavements, his Afcon shootout heroics and the prospect of facing Haaland

Ronwen Williams can pinpoint when his life changed for ever. In 2002, the future South Africa captain was a 10-year-old from Gelvandale, a notorious suburb of Gqeberha, formerly known as Port Elizabeth, when his cousin was shot dead while working as a security guard.

“He was killed around the corner from where we were playing in the street,” Williams says. “The next thing you know, my cousin was being rushed to hospital. The area was filled with gangsterism, alcohol and drug abuse.”

Continue reading...

title: England’s female cricketers land 30% pay rises and new multiyear deals
summary:
• Eighteen ECB contracts on offer worth £90,000-£130,000
  • Details agreed before England flew to UAE for World T20

England’s female cricketers will receive pay rises of more than 30% when the next round of central contracts are issued in October, with some multiyear deals on offer for the first time.

The historic move to longer-term contracts follows the England and Wales Cricket Board giving multiyear deals to some of England’s male stars last year and will be a major boost to Heather Knight’s side before the Women’s T20 World Cup in the United Arab Emirates, which begins next week.

Continue reading...

title: Jofra Archer back up to speed for England before decisive Australia ODI
summary:
The bowler produced his fastest spell in five years, helping send the one-day series to its finale in Bristol at 2-2

﻿After England’s barnstorming series-leveller against Australia at Lord’s, it is time for the two teams to invoke the spirit of the Pet Shop Boys – or the Village People, for those of a certain vintage – and go west. The only problem for Sunday’s tantalising decider in Bristol is an afternoon forecast that is more Wet, Wet, Wet.

At the Metro Bank One-Day Cup final officials invoked common sense for its reserve day on Monday and scheduled a 20-over match before the expected rain. The regulations may prove more rigid for an international match, however, raising the prospect of a 2-2 draw between these two countries for the second summer in a row. It may not be the Ashes, but it would still be a bit of an anticlimax.

Continue reading...
